awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Repeated Adaptive Radiation in the  Coevolutionary History of Birds and Feather Lice
awd_abstract_narration:
This project uses feather lice from birds as a model system to better understand how ecological interactions shape evolutionary patterns. Avian feather lice have repeatedly evolved particular morphologies, they live on different parts of the host's body and they differ in how they escape host defense. For example, some species of lice have evolved to be very thin and narrow and can fit between the barbs of the wing feathers where they cannot be easily removed, while others have evolved large mandibles to bite down on the feathers. The purpose of this study is to better understand the process of how these repeated adaptations have occurred in response to interactions with their hosts. This proposal will involve extensive training of three graduate students and a postdoc in both molecular and morphological analysis and support further development of the software aTRAM. A module for undergraduate education will be developed in collaboration with NSF funded Biodiversity Literacy in Undergraduate Education (BLUE).

	
To study repeated evolutionary adaptation this study will use genomic, morphological, and species interaction data to elucidate the pattern and processes underlying repeated co-evolutionary events. The main objectives are to 1) sequence whole genomes of 280 species of feather lice to determine the number of repeated adaptive radiations in this group; 2) use morphological measurements from both CT scanned and slide mounted specimens to examine morphological convergence with each ecomorph; 3) use these sequenced genomes to identify genes with signatures of selection that are associated with ecomorph transitions; and 4) compare the phylogeny of the lice with that of their avian hosts to evaluate whether ecomorph transitions occur more often at major host switching events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Repeated evolutionary events are excellent candidates to study to understand the ecological, genetic and evolutionary underpinnings of evolutionary events. Avian feather lice spend their entire life cycle on their avian hosts and have repeatedly evolved morphological features depending on where they live on the bird’s body. These lice feed on feathers, and birds have evolved defense mechanisms against lice including preening with the bill and scratching with the feet. The morphological features the lice have evolved are thought to be in response to the defense mechanism the bird uses on different parts of its body. These morphological features termed ecomorphs have repeatedly evolved in lice that live across avian groups. In this project we examined the morphological, ecological and genetic mechanisms associated with repeated ecomorph evolution in these lice.

We first examined morphological features in the head shape and chewing muscles of these ecomorphs and determined that the generalist ecomorph form overlaps the morphological space of the other three ecomorphs, whereas each of the other ecomorphs reside in their own more extreme ecomorph space overlapping only with the generalist form. To understand the evolutionary events that led to these ecomorphs, we built a phylogenomic tree of 250 lice and compared that to a tree of their hosts. We examined transitions in ecomorph with respect to host switching on the tree and found that the ancestral ecomorph was likely a generalist and that most ecomorph transitions moved from the generalist state to one of the more extreme ecomorph states, often corresponding with a host switching event. Finally, we examined ~3,000 genes across 56 species of lice and found in some cases the evolution of ecomorph does correlate with the same genetic signatures, particularly for head and body lice ecomorphs but for wing and generalist ecomorphs other genetic mechanisms may come into play (e.g. gene expression). Taken together our results provide a picture of repeat ecomorph evolution occurring in response to a generalist louse switching hosts and evolving into the other ecomorph groups likely in response to selective pressure from the host.

This project had a number of broader impacts involved. We developed a tool called exon stitching for the software aTRAM – automated Target Restricted Assembly Method that enables users to extract exon sequences from aTRAM assemblies. Second, we developed an education module on BLUE – Biodiversity Literacy in Undergraduate Education that has been downloaded >500 times. Six manuscripts have been produced. One graduate student was able to graduate with her PhD using data from this project and one postdoc was trained in CT scanning and morphological analysis.
